Award.AwardTitle: Immunity in an Ecological Context: The Intersection of Host Physiology, Medicinal Food Plants and Microbiomes in a Natural Butterfly-parasite System
Award.AbstractNarration:
Almost all organisms are attacked by parasites. Recent studies have shown that many animals, from butterflies to chimpanzees, can protect themselves against parasites through self-medication (the use of anti-parasitic substances or diets). However, the mechanisms by which medication behaviors reduce parasite infection and disease remain poorly understood. This project focuses on monarch butterflies and their protozoan parasites. Monarch caterpillars are specialist feeders on milkweed plants, and milkweeds vary in their concentrations and toxicity of chemicals called cardenolides. When feeding on toxic milkweed, monarchs become less sick, and infected female butterflies preferentially lay their eggs on toxic milkweed to reduce disease in their offspring. This project will determine whether toxic milkweeds reduce disease by directly killing parasites, by increasing the immune response of monarchs, or by providing monarchs with a gut flora that prevents parasite infection. Beyond monarch butterflies, this project has broad relevance to other animals, many of which use medicinal plants. The parasites studied here are related to parasites causing disease in agricultural animals and humans, thus elucidating the anti-parasitic activity of milkweed chemicals could have future applications for treating disease. The project will also integrate research with education, by training graduate and undergraduate students, including those from underrepresented groups in science. The researchers will also develop lesson modules with the Wylde Center, an Atlanta-based non-profit organization that teaches environmental awareness through community-garden based outdoor programs. As part of this, the project will directly contribute to the science education of thousands of K-12 students.

Hosts have evolved a range of defenses against their parasites, including behavioral and microbial defenses. Such defenses may have important consequences for the evolution of physiological immunity, but research on the interplay between physiological immunity, behavioral immunity and microbial protection remains scarce. This project will study the interaction between monarch butterflies, their milkweed host plants and their protozoan parasites to address three hypotheses: (1) behavioral use of medicinal milkweeds directly decreases parasite infection, rendering physiological immunity superfluous and reducing investment in such immune mechanisms; (2) medicinal milkweeds do not reduce monarch immunity but instead exert their protective effects by enhancing physiological immune responses; and (3) medicinal milkweeds modulate monarch midgut microbiota to a state that confers resistance to parasite infection. These hypotheses will be addressed by elucidating immune responses differentially mounted upon infection of butterflies from resistant and susceptible populations, comparing anti-parasite immune responses in monarchs fed on medicinal and non-medicinal milkweed plants, and by analyzing the effects of milkweed secondary and nutritional chemicals on monarch immunity and resistance. In addition, comparison of the midgut microbiota of monarchs reared on medicinal and non-medicinal milkweeds will be coupled with experiments manipulating gut microbiota to test for the effect of medicinal milkweed microbial communities on monarch resistance to infection. The researchers will use a combination of fieldwork, controlled experiments and next generation sequencing technology, including the use of RNASeq to quantify differential immune responses and MiSeq to quantify bacterial and fungal caterpillar gut communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Almost all organisms are attacked by parasites. Recent studies have shown that many animals, from butterflies to chimpanzees, can protect themselves against parasites through self-medication, the use of anti-parasitic substances or diets. However, the mechanisms by which medication behaviors reduce parasite infection and disease remain poorly understood. This project focused on monarch butterflies and their protozoan parasites. Monarch caterpillars are specialist feeders on milkweed plants, and milkweeds vary in their concentrations and toxicity of chemicals called cardenolides. When feeding on toxic milkweed, monarchs become less sick, and diseased female butterflies preferentially lay their eggs on toxic milkweed to reduce disease in their offspring. This project determined whether toxic milkweeds reduce disease by directly killing parasites, by increasing the monarch?s immune response or by providing monarchs with a gut flora that prevents parasite infection.

 

This project found further evidence that high-cardenolide milkweed reduces parasite infection. As part of this project, the researchers elucidated the immune responses that monarch butterflies use against their common protozoan parasite, Ophryocystis elektrosirrha. This parasite forms spores on the adult butterfly, and these are transmitted to eggs and milkweed leaves when females lay eggs. The spores are then ingested by monarch caterpillars, which then become infected. Interestingly, using a suite of common insect immune measures, such as the concentration of blood cells and the formation of antimicrobial peptides, the researchers did not find evidence of upregulation of these measures, suggesting that monarch caterpillars do not increase their immune responses when infected. Moreover, when measuring the expression of more than 100 immune genes, the researchers again did not find an upregulation of immunity in monarch caterpillars. On the contrary, when monarchs were reared on medicinal milkweed, they down-regulated immune genes, suggesting that the use of medicinal milkweed reduces investment in immunity.

 

To test whether medicinal milkweed can reduce parasite infection through altering the monarch gut flora, the researchers first determined that caterpillars reared on different milkweeds have different microbes. Then, they developed a procedure to carry our fecal transplants, transferring either caterpillar frass (feces) or the microbes derived from those feces to recipient caterpillars. Importantly, these procedures showed that caterpillars that were reared on non-medicinal milkweed but obtained microbes from caterpillars reared on medicinal milkweed experienced lower parasite infection and disease. Fecal transplants increased gut microbe diversity, as well as abundance, and these factors increased resistance to parasite infection. Overall, the experiments on milkweed cardenolides, monarch immunity and the gut flora suggest that medicinal mikweeds act against parasites through direct toxicity and through modulation of the gut flora, and that monarch medication can reduce investment in immunity.

 

Beyond monarch butterflies, this project has broad relevance to other animals, many of which use medicinal diets. The finding that diet affects disease resistance through modulation of the gut flora has relevance for many other animals in which relationships between diet and disease, diet and fur flora, and fur flora and disease have been shown in isolation. Moreover, the finding that animal self-medication can reduce investment in immunity is relevant to other self-medicating animals, but also to agricultural animals, in which large-scale medication is often used prophylactically. Indeed, the results from this project would suggest that such wide use of medication could breed immune-weakened animals.

 

This project has also integrated research with education, having trained two graduate students (one underrepresented minority), a postdoc (underrepresented minority) and undergraduate and high-school students (including those from underrepresented groups in science). The researchers have also developed lesson modules on pollinators and microbes with Melanie Heckman, Education Specialist at the Fernbank Science Center. These hands-on lesson plans, "Pollination Power" and "Meet the Microbes", have been offered to almost 7,000 second and fifth graders in the Dekalb County school system. Of these students, an estimated 58% are from low-income families and 78% are from groups underrepresented in science. Assessments of learning based on pre- and post-lesson surveys indicates high learning gains in topics related to pollinator biology and microbiology, as well as increased interest in these topics. Ms. Heckman also hosted a professional development workshop for ten Dekalb County teachers, with an aim to develop pollinator gardens at their respective schools.
